Expectation1: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation1: Leadership needs a prompt reply to confirm details for an external partner.
Expectation2: Secure packages and confirm successful delivery
Situation2: Requesting a signature upon delivery for moderately valuable items
Story: My phone buzzed with a new email just as I pulled up to the client’s office, a stack of moderately valuable packages in the back seat. I glanced at the screen—leadership needed a prompt reply to confirm details for an external partner, and the subject line was marked “urgent.” As a colleague, I knew the expectation: respond quickly, keep the project moving, don’t let the team down. But as a delivery person, I had my own standards to uphold. The packages needed to be secured, and I had to get a signature for each one—no shortcuts, no exceptions. I could see the client’s receptionist through the glass doors, waiting for me. My mind raced. If I paused to answer the email, I’d risk being late and possibly missing the recipient, which could mean rescheduling the delivery and breaking protocol. But if I went straight in, I’d leave my team hanging, maybe even jeopardize the partnership. My hands tightened on the steering wheel as I weighed the demands, feeling the pressure of both roles pulling me in opposite directions.
